newsitem.title: UK: British manufacturing grows in March, but jobs axed.
newsitem.headline: British manufacturing grows in March, but jobs axed.

text.p: Britain's manufacturing sector expanded in March for the 10th month in a row but the pace of growth eased as firms axed jobs to cut costs, a leading business survey said Tuesday.
The Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply said its purchasing managers' index stood at a seasonally adjusted 52.9 in March compared with 53.4 in February.
The institute said the fall in the index was a result of a drop in manufacturing employment, the first since May.
"A slightly higher number of firms cut staffing levels as part of effiency-boosting rationalisation programmes, such as downsizing, than recruited new staff," the institute said.
A reading over 50 indicates expansion in the sector, with the decline in the index level showing the pace of growth eased.
The survey said new orders registered higher growth in March with the principal source of demand coming from the home market.
And contrary to other business surveys, export orders also rose and at a faster rate than in February, largely due to faster growth in the economies of key European trading partners.
Manufacturing firms have complained recently that the pound's dramatic appreciation -- 15 percent on a trade-weighted basis since August -- is checking demand for British goods abroad.
